item.title: Pediatricians Advise No Fruit Juice Until Kids Are 1
item.description: May 22, 2017 - Older kids should limit the amount of juice they drink too. Whole fruit is better than juice because it contains fiber, which slows the absorption of sugar and fills you up the way juice doesn't.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 22, 2017 - Older kids should limit the amount of juice they drink too. Whole fruit is better than juice because it contains fiber, which slows the absorption of sugar and fills you up the way juice doesn't. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/22/528970924/pediatricians-advise-no-fruit-juice-until-kids-are-1

item.title: Cloud Eggs: The Latest Instagram Food Fad Is Actually Centuries Old
item.description: May 21, 2017 - The fanciful dish was meant to impress nearly 400 years ago, so don't roll your eyes at photos of these pretty edibles: They're actually a time-honored tradition tinged with a bit of kitchen science.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 21, 2017 - The fanciful dish was meant to impress nearly 400 years ago, so don't roll your eyes at photos of these pretty edibles: They're actually a time-honored tradition tinged with a bit of kitchen science. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/21/529127751/cloud-eggs-the-latest-instagram-food-fad-is-actually-centuries-old

item.title: Why Brain Scientists Are Still Obsessed With The Curious Case Of Phineas Gage
item.description: May 21, 2017 - In 1848, a railroad worker survived an accident that drove a 13-pound iron bar through his head. The injury changed his personality, and our understanding of the brain.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 21, 2017 - In 1848, a railroad worker survived an accident that drove a 13-pound iron bar through his head. The injury changed his personality, and our understanding of the brain. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/21/528966102/why-brain-scientists-are-still-obsessed-with-the-curious-case-of-phineas-gage

item.title: Scientists Sneak A Peek At How Ladybugs Fold Their Wings
item.description: May 20, 2017 - Ladybugs are famous for their spotted wing cases. But researchers in Japan were interested in what was happening under that colorful exterior: How delicate wings were folding origami-like into place.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 20, 2017 - Ladybugs are famous for their spotted wing cases. But researchers in Japan were interested in what was happening under that colorful exterior: How delicate wings were folding origami-like into place. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/20/529148056/scientists-sneak-a-peek-at-how-ladybugs-fold-their-wings

item.title: We Have Always Been Bored â€” 'Yawn' Wonders Why
item.description: May 20, 2017 - Mary Mann's new book digs into a phenomenon as old as humanity: boredom. Why do we get bored? Is there a cure? Yawn is a thoughtful read, but its mix of autobiography and scholarship doesn't jell.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 20, 2017 - Mary Mann's new book digs into a phenomenon as old as humanity: boredom. Why do we get bored? Is there a cure? Yawn is a thoughtful read, but its mix of autobiography and scholarship doesn't jell. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/20/527998428/we-have-always-been-bored-yawn-wonders-why

item.title: Scientists One Step Closer To 3-D-Printed Ovaries To Treat Infertility
item.description: May 20, 2017 - Researchers printed gelatin scaffolds into which they placed ovarian tissue, and then implanted the new organs in mice. Three out of seven female mice produced healthy offspring using the technology.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 20, 2017 - Researchers printed gelatin scaffolds into which they placed ovarian tissue, and then implanted the new organs in mice. Three out of seven female mice produced healthy offspring using the technology. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/20/528646323/scientists-one-step-closer-to-3-d-printed-ovaries-to-treat-infertility

item.title: Public To EPA On Cutting Regulations: 'No!'
item.description: May 19, 2017 - The Environmental Protection Agency asked for public input on "job-killing regulations" and has received more than 28,000 comments, many of which urge the agency not to roll back protections.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 19, 2017 - The Environmental Protection Agency asked for public input on "job-killing regulations" and has received more than 28,000 comments, many of which urge the agency not to roll back protections. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/19/528993681/public-to-epa-on-cutting-regulations-no

item.title: Energy Companies Urge Trump To Remain In Paris Climate Agreement
item.description: May 18, 2017 - Shell CEO Ben van Beurden says he wants the U.S. to remain in the 2015 Paris climate accord. Energy companies like Exxon Mobil and BP have also urged President Trump to continue supporting the deal.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 18, 2017 - Shell CEO Ben van Beurden says he wants the U.S. to remain in the 2015 Paris climate accord. Energy companies like Exxon Mobil and BP have also urged President Trump to continue supporting the deal. http://www.npr.org/2017/05/18/528998592/energy-companies-urge-trump-to-remain-in-paris-climate-agreement

item.title: Scientists Glued Fake Caterpillars On Plants Worldwide. Here's What Happened
item.description: May 18, 2017 - Predators that attacked the clay caterpillars left telltale bite marks, which were later analyzed to help figure the critter's risk of getting eaten. That analysis revealed a striking pattern.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 18, 2017 - Predators that attacked the clay caterpillars left telltale bite marks, which were later analyzed to help figure the critter's risk of getting eaten. That analysis revealed a striking pattern. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/18/528969334/scientists-glued-fake-caterpillars-on-plants-worldwide-heres-what-happened

item.title: Stormy Weather: Are We Well Prepared For The Next Disaster?
item.description:
May 18, 2017 - Is the country well prepared for a summer of record heat, flash floods and extreme weather?
- http://the1a.org/shows/2017-05-18/stormy-weather-are-we-well-prepared-for-the-next-disaster
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)

item.title: Will The Government Help Farmers Adapt To A Changing Climate?
item.description: May 18, 2017 - The livelihoods of farmers and ranchers are intimately tied to weather and the environment. But they may no longer be able to depend on government research to help them adapt to climate change.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 18, 2017 - The livelihoods of farmers and ranchers are intimately tied to weather and the environment. But they may no longer be able to depend on government research to help them adapt to climate change. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/18/528133891/will-the-government-help-farmers-adapt-to-a-changing-climate

item.title: Is 'Internet Addiction' Real?
item.description: May 18, 2017 - What started out as web surfing by a healthy teen descended into online obsession and isolation. Was it depression, internet addiction or both? Whatever you call it, rehab is now part of the answer.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 18, 2017 - What started out as web surfing by a healthy teen descended into online obsession and isolation. Was it depression, internet addiction or both? Whatever you call it, rehab is now part of the answer. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/18/527799301/is-internet-addiction-real

item.title: Many Of California's Salmon Populations Unlikely To Survive The Century
item.description: May 17, 2017 - Climate change, dams and agriculture are threatening Chinook salmon, the iconic fish at the core of the state's fishing industry, a report predicts. And 23 other fish species are also at risk.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - Climate change, dams and agriculture are threatening Chinook salmon, the iconic fish at the core of the state's fishing industry, a report predicts. And 23 other fish species are also at risk. http://www.npr.org/sections/thesalt/2017/05/17/528826774/many-of-california-s-salmon-populations-unlikely-to-survive-the-century

item.title: Tragic Love Triangle Is Sad For Lonely Rare Snail, Still Good For Science
item.description: May 17, 2017 - A garden snail with a rare genetic condition can't mate with normal snails; scientists launch an international search for a mate; two possible mates are found. But they mate with each other instead.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - A garden snail with a rare genetic condition can't mate with normal snails; scientists launch an international search for a mate; two possible mates are found. But they mate with each other instead. http://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/05/17/528796939/tragic-love-triangle-is-sad-for-lonely-rare-snail-still-good-for-science

item.title: Orangutan Moms Are The Primate Champs Of Breast-Feeding
item.description: May 17, 2017 - Orangutans breast-feed up to nine years, longer than any other primate. That may help offspring survive food shortages. But humans may have gained a survival advantage from weaning earlier.
item.itunes:author: podcasts@npr.org (NPR Podcasts)
item.itunes:summary: May 17, 2017 - Orangutans breast-feed up to nine years, longer than any other primate. That may help offspring survive food shortages. But humans may have gained a survival advantage from weaning earlier. http://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2017/05/17/528776636/orangutan-moms-are-the-primate-champs-of-breast-feeding
